26 Alabama Licensing 26 Regulation Licensing Requirements License Status LICENSING REQUIREMENTS Activities requiring a license Qualifications for a salesperson's license Application and documentation Temporary licensure Original licensure License renewal Reciprocal license Co-brokering To protect the general public, Alabama law created the Alabama Real Estate Commission to license and regulate real estate professionals. For AREC to accomplish this goal, Alabama license law specifies which activities require a license and how to obtain a license. Activities requiring a license Alabama law requires any person, sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation, branch office, or legal business organization engaging in the practice of real estate for compensation to be licensed as a real estate broker or salesperson. The license must also be on active status to perform such activity. Compensation includes fees, commissions, or other valuable consideration received from another person in exchange for performing certain activities. Performing licensed activities with the intention or expectation of receiving compensation is considered the same as actually receiving compensation for purposes of defining whether a license is required. Engaging in the practice of real estate includes:  offering or selling, exchanging, purchasing, renting, or leasing real estate located in Alabama  negotiating the listing, sale, exchange, purchase, rental, or leasing of real estate located in Alabama  listing for sale, rental, lease, exchange, or trade any real estate located in Alabama  auctioning any real estate located in Alabama  optioning real estate located in Alabama  locating for purchase, rent, or lease any real estate located in Alabama 442 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

 procuring prospects for the purpose of selling, exchanging, leasing, or renting of any real estate located in Alabama  presenting oneself as being able to perform any act for which a license is required Again, engaging in any of these activities for compensation within the State of Alabama requires an active Alabama real estate license. Qualifications for a salesperson's license Alabama requires that the license for a broker or salesperson be registered to a specific real estate office. The license will be issued and held only by a person who meets all of the following requirements. Personal requirements. All license applicants must be trustworthy and competent to transact real estate business in a way that safeguards public interest. The applicant must also meet the following requirements:  at least 19 years old  U.S. citizen or legally present in the U.S. with the appropriate documentation from the U.S. government or an alien with permanent U.S. resident status  resident of any state in the U.S.  no rejection or revocation of an application or license in any state within 2 years prior to the Alabama application date on any grounds other than failure to pass the written examination; applicants whose license has been revoked must meet all requirements for an original license and must be approved by the AREC Nonresident applicants. If the applicant is a nonresident of Alabama and does not hold a current license in another state but wishes to practice real estate in Alabama, he or she must apply for a salesperson's license. This nonresident applicant must show proof of all of the following:  high school graduate or the equivalent  successful completion of 60 hours of AREC approved real estate coursework  any other information the Commission requires If the applicant is a nonresident and holds a current license in another state, even if he or she becomes an Alabama resident, the individual must apply for a reciprocal salesperson license in Alabama. (Reciprocal license requirements and application procedures are covered in detail later in this chapter.) Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 443

Any nonresident applicant for an Alabama original license or for a reciprocal license must also sign an affidavit agreeing that  AREC has jurisdiction over the applicant and his or her activities  he or she will be subject to the same investigations and disciplinary actions as Alabama resident licensees  civil actions may be taken against him or her in any Alabama court of competent jurisdiction  the applicant appoints the AREC Executive Director or Assistant Executive Director as his or her agent who will be served with any disciplinary, judicial, or other legal notices  any service upon his or her agent will be the same as service upon him or herself  certified copies of the appointment of agent will be sufficient evidence just the same as the original appointment  the appointment will be effective for as long as the applicant has any liability remaining in Alabama  the applicant is bound by all of the Alabama Real Estate License Law just as if he or she were an Alabama resident Criminal backgrounds and fingerprints. The AREC may reject the application of anyone who has been convicted of or pleaded guilty or nolo contendere to a felony or to a crime involving moral turpitude. If an applicant has such a conviction or guilty plea, he or she may file an "Application for Determination of Licensing Eligibility" form with the Commission. The Commission will review the conviction and determine if the applicant is eligible for licensure in Alabama. The AREC requires both state and national criminal history checks to be performed on any applicant for licensure. The applicant must submit any required information and fingerprints to the Commission, to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to the Alabama State Law Enforcement Agency or its successor, or to a fingerprint processing service approved by the Commission. Fingerprints are to be submitted on the approved fingerprint card. To avoid having the application denied based on faulty fingerprints, the following steps should be taken:  fingerprints taken by an authorized official at a law enforcement agency  fingerprint card completely filled out at the top and signed by the person being fingerprinted and the official who takes the fingerprints  fingerprint card containing only quality fingerprint impressions that follow the examples given on the back of the card  a properly executed application to review criminal history record information submitted with the fingerprint card  card examined by the official taking the fingerprints to ensure it is filled out correctly and that the fingerprint impressions are adequate 444 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

The AREC may then use the criminal history to determine the qualifications and fitness of the applicant to hold a real estate license. The applicant is responsible for the cost of the criminal history check which must be current to the date of license issuance. These requirements are the same for both salesperson applicants and broker applicants. Education requirements. All applicants for licensure in Alabama must be a high school graduate or the equivalent. Applicants must also complete the required pre-license coursework. Test requirements. In addition to all other requirements for qualifying for a salesperson's license, each applicant for licensure must take and pass a written examination. The Commission will either conduct the examination or contract with an independent testing agency who will prepare, conduct, and grade the examination. The fee for the examination will be set in the Commission's contract with the independent testing agency. Application and documentation Documentation. All applicants for licensure in Alabama are required to submit documentation in proof of age, citizenship or legal residency status, Alabama residency, and high school graduation or equivalent. Alabama nonresidents applying for a reciprocal license must submit proof of licensure in their resident states. The applicant may provide documentation in proof of age in the form of any of the following:  a valid driver's license  a U.S. passport  a birth certificate  any other documentation the AREC deems acceptable Applicants for licensure must also provide proof of U.S. citizenship, permanent residency, or legal presence status. This proof may be submitted in the form of any of the following:  a driver's license  a non-driver identification  a U.S. birth certificate  a permanent resident card (green card)  a U.S. visa  any other document issued by the U.S. indicating legal presence in the United States Proof of Alabama state residency can be submitted in the form of any of the following:  a driver's license Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 445

 a car tag receipt  a deed to a home  a lease agreement on a home or apartment  a property tax bill  a voter's registration card  any other document the AREC deems acceptable Nonresidents holding an Alabama license who become Alabama residents must submit a change of address to the AREC within 10 days of residency, along with any other license status changes. Applicants must show one of the following as proof of meeting high school completion requirements:  high school diploma  high school transcripts showing graduation date  GED certificate  College diploma  College transcripts showing completion of at least two full terms  DD-214 showing verification of high school completion Applicants who were home schooled in the U.S. must provide a notarized transcript and a letter of recommendation from the home school group leader. Home school diplomas are not accepted. Applicants who completed high school outside the U.S. must provide either of the following:  a transcript from a U.S. college showing sufficient high school education for admittance into a college education program  a Document-by-Document Evaluation Report verifying the foreign education was equivalent to an American high school education Temporary licensure Temporary license education and test requirements. A person wishing to conduct real estate business in Alabama is required to first obtain a temporary license prior to completing post-license courses and obtaining an original (permanent) salesperson license. To obtain a temporary license, the individual must complete an approved 60- hour pre-license course. The pre-license course must be completed within 1 year from the start date or the student will not receive credit for the classes completed and will need to start the course again. At least 80% of the course hours must be presented by live instruction unless the course is an Association of Real Estate License Law Officials (ARELLO) certified distance education course. The student must then apply for and schedule the salesperson license state examination. Applicants must pass the examination within 6 months after the completion date of the pre-license course. Failure to meet the time frame 446 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

requirement will result in the applicant having to again complete the pre-license course. Temporary license application and issuance. Within 90 days after passing the license examination, the applicant must find an Alabama-licensed qualifying broker under whose supervision the salesperson applicant will work. The qualifying broker must sign and submit a sworn statement of his or her belief of the applicant's honesty, trustworthiness, and good reputation and of the broker's willingness to accept responsibility for the salesperson's actions. After passing the examination, securing the qualifying broker, and meeting all other requirements for licensure, including paying the $30 Recovery Fund fee, the applicant will be issued a temporary license certificate. The temporary license is valid for 1 year. Post-license education. During the 12 months of temporary licensure, the salesperson must complete a 30-hour post-license course, apply for an original salesperson license, and pay all associated application fees. The salesperson should complete the post-license course and apply for the original license within the first 6 months of temporary licensure. If the salesperson does not complete the course within the first 6 months, the license will automatically be placed on inactive status. The salesperson then has the remaining 6 months to complete the course and apply for an original license. If the salesperson fails to complete the post-license course within 12 months, the temporary license will automatically expire and lapse. Temporary licenses may not be renewed. Holding a temporary license is required for enrollment in the post-license course. As with the pre-license course, a 90% attendance rate is required in live instruction courses. Original licensure Application process. After completing the post-license course, salespersons holding a temporary license must apply for an original license on or before the date the temporary license expires. The salesperson must submit the original license application, appropriate fees, and proof of completion of the post-license course to the Alabama Real Estate Commission on or before midnight on the last day of the month 1 year from the issuance of the temporary license. For example, if Joe was issued a temporary license on April 4, 2027, he must apply for his original license by midnight on April 30, 2028. Joe must also have completed the post-license course and paid the license fee prior to that date and time. However, keep in mind that Joe could obtain his original license sooner if he completes the post-license course during the first 6 months he has his temporary license. Otherwise, his temporary license will be placed on inactive status after the first 6 months and will remain inactive until he completes the coursework. If he doesn't complete the post-license course and apply for his original license within the 12 months, his temporary license will lapse, and he will have to start the entire process all over again. Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 447

Applicants who paid the Recovery Fund fee when applying for a temporary license are not required to pay the fee again for original licensure. Therefore, using the above example, if Joe paid the Recovery Fund fee when he applied for his temporary license, he is not required to pay it again when he applies for his original license. License renewal All licenses, including inactive licenses, must be renewed to remain current. A license may be renewed by filing an AREC license renewal form or by utilizing the renewal option available at www.arec.alabama.gov. The licensee must also pay a renewal fee and complete continuing education courses prior to renewal. If the licensee is on active status, the Commission will mail the renewal form to the licensee's place of business. If the licensee is on inactive status, the form will be mailed to the licensee's residence. The Commission will mail the form prior to August 1 of the final year of the license period. If the licensee does not receive the form by August 1, he or she must notify the AREC by August 10. The form may only be used for license renewal and not for any other reason, such as a license transfer. Renewal dates. The license period is 2 years, ending in even numbered years. The license will expire at midnight on September 30 of the final year of the 2- year license period. Renewals and renewal fees are due by August 31 of the final year of the license period. Licenses renewed between September 1 and September 30 will be charged a late renewal penalty in addition to the renewal fee. Licenses not renewed by September 30 will expire and be placed on inactive status on October 1. Because the license period always ends in an even numbered year, the license must be renewed in the next even numbered year, regardless of when it was issued. For example, if the license was issued in April 2025, it would need to be renewed in 2026, the next even numbered year. Similarly, if a license was originally issued in April 2026, the license would need to be renewed that same year because 2026 is an even numbered year. Expired licenses may still be renewed during the 12 months following the expiration date. If the license is not renewed during this 12-month period, the license will lapse. The individual will then need to meet all the same requirements of licensure applicable to individuals who have never been licensed and reapply for licensure. By not renewing the license by the September 30 deadline and then by allowing the license to lapse after the 12-month renewal period, the individual will no longer be considered a licensee and will no longer receive correspondence from the AREC. Under certain circumstances, the Commission may determine the existence of a hardship for the licensee and allow an extended renewal date with payment of renewal fees and penalties. In addition to submitting the license renewal form and renewal fees, as well as renewal penalties if applicable, the licensee must submit proof of completion of approved continuing education courses. 448 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

Continuing education. Alabama licensees are required to complete 15 hours of continuing education courses by September 30 of the final year of every 2-year license period. If the licensee fails to meet this deadline, his or her license will be placed on inactive status on October 1; and the licensee will be required to follow all reactivation procedures. While on inactive status, the licensee will not be allowed to perform any real estate activities that require a license. Salesperson licensees fulfilling continuing education requirements may only take approved courses from approved schools. To meet continuing education requirements, the courses must include the following:  Three Hours of “Risk Management: Initial Contact to Accepted Offer.”  12 hours of any AREC-approved courses, often referred to as electives. These courses must be "core" real estate courses and must assist the licensee in fulfilling AREC's mission of protecting the public. Each course must be at least 3 hours of instruction. The hours may include such courses as  license law  RECAD (Real Estate Consumer’s Agency And Disclosure Act)  real estate ethics  real estate financing  appraisal and valuation  fair housing  truth-in-lending  agency relationships  agency disclosure  liability of real estate agents  writing contracts  handling escrow funds  environmental issues  negotiating techniques  listing and buyer presentations  writing and presenting offers  showing property  sales skills  communication skills  marketing  certain financial calculator courses  computer courses which are real estate specific  how to utilize technology in the practice of real estate Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 449

Examples of unacceptable subject matter include  motivational courses  personal development courses  sales meetings  in-house training  orientation courses Brokers and associate brokers must complete the required broker CE course and 9 hours of elective courses. All course topics and content are subject to approval by the Commission. The licensee must attend 100% of the course hours to be awarded continuing education credit. If the licensee can provide proof of attendance, he or she does not need to pass the courses to satisfy the requirements for renewal. A licensee who completes an approved continuing education course in another state may receive credit for the course in Alabama by submitting the appropriate documentation to the Commission. Documentation must include verification of course approval by the other state, the number of hours for which the course is approved, and proof of course completion. Courses taken out of state will be credited as elective courses only. If the licensee completes more than the required 15 hours of course work, the excess hours may not be carried over and applied to subsequent license period requirements. If the licensee serves as a member of the State Legislature during the license period, that service can substitute for the 15 hours of course work for continuing education. A licensee who has been licensed for less than 1 year and is applying for first time renewal is not required to complete the 15 hours of continuing education course work for that renewal period. The licensee's post-license course counts as continuing education credit for the first license period. A reciprocal licensee who has held an Alabama license for less than 1 year is not required to complete continuing education for the first renewal of his or her license. This exemption only applies to reciprocal licensees who received an Alabama license after September 30, 2015. Exemptions from continuing education requirements. Alabama law allows for two possible exemptions from the requirement to complete continuing education before renewal: 450 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

 licensees who turn 65 years old on or before September 30, 2000, and have been licensed for 10 years prior to that  licensees on inactive status Although inactive licensees are required to renew their licenses every 2 years, this exemption means they do not need to complete continuing education courses every license period while on inactive status. They will, however, be required to complete the 15-hour continuing education requirement prior to reactivating their licenses. Reciprocal license If an individual holds a current real estate license in a qualifying state other than Alabama, he or she may obtain a reciprocal license in Alabama. The license in the other state must not be a reciprocal or non-resident license and must be on either active or inactive status. A qualifying state is one in which the applicant has completed pre-license course work and passed an examination covering general (national) real estate and state law for the state in which the examination was taken. Applicants for a reciprocal license must provide a Certificate of Licensure issued within the preceding 120 days from the state where the applicant is licensed. The Certificate must show the following:  the applicant's name and address,  type of license,  the license status over the previous 36 months,  any record of disciplinary action, and  the type of examination the applicant took and passed. An applicant for a reciprocal license must also complete 6 hours of AREC- approved course work in Alabama real estate and pass a written examination on Alabama real estate with a score of 70% or higher. The applicant must pass the examination within 6 months of completing the 6-hour course work. Failure to meet this deadline will result in the applicant needing to complete the course work again. After completing the course work and passing the examination, the applicant must then submit an application and the appropriate fees for a reciprocal license. An applicant for a reciprocal license will pay the same licensure and Recovery Fund fees as an Alabama license applicant. Reciprocal license applicants who hold a salesperson license in the other state must apply for a reciprocal salesperson license in Alabama, while applicants who hold a broker license in the other state must apply for a reciprocal broker license in Alabama. After the reciprocal license is issued, the licensee must either complete Alabama- required continuing education or show proof that his or her other state license is still active. Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 451

Continuing education requirements for reciprocal licensees. Reciprocal licensees have options regarding fulfilling continuing education requirements for Alabama license renewal:  the licensee may complete 15 hours of Alabama-approved continuing education course work, including three hours of risk management from initial contact to contract; the remaining 12 hours can be taken in another state if the licensee provides proof of attendance in the courses, verification that the course was approved by any real estate commission, and proof of the number of hours for which the course was approved. Broker licensees must complete the required broker CE course  the licensee may submit a certification of licensure from the regulatory agency in the state where the pre-license courses and licensing examination were taken; the certification must include:  type of license  the current active status of the license  the company that holds the license  verification the pre-license course work requirements were met in that state  verification that a full state and national licensing examination was passed in that state  the certification must be dated no earlier than June 1 and must be an original certification unless it is faxed to the AREC Co-brokering A principal broker who is licensed in a state other than Alabama may practice real estate in Alabama if that broker signs a written agreement with a qualifying broker licensed in Alabama. The agreement is called a co-brokerage agreement. The agreement must specify each parcel of property the nonresident will be handling, the financial terms of the agreement and any other material terms of the agreement. Prior to signing the agreement, the Alabama qualifying broker must confirm the nonresident broker is licensed as a principal broker in the other state. A copy of the agreement must be filed with the AREC within 10 days of execution. The Alabama qualifying broker must require a listing or joint listing of any property involved in the agreement. The Alabama qualifying broker must also supervise any property showings and negotiations the nonresident broker performs. Any advertising of Alabama real estate must include the name of the Alabama qualifying broker. All earnest money associated with transactions covered under the co-brokerage agreement must be held in escrow by the Alabama qualifying broker unless both the buyer and seller agree in writing to a different arrangement. The agreement must specify all material terms, including financial terms. An out-of-state 452 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

principal broker who is working under a co-brokerage agreement is limited to three real estate transactions totaling less than $50 million in sales each calendar year. This limit would, however, allow transactions of multiple properties within the same portfolio. The Alabama qualifying broker is liable for the nonresident broker's actions associated with the agreement as well as the Alabama qualifying broker's own actions. However, by signing the co-brokerage agreement, the nonresident broker agrees to abide by Alabama law and by the rules of the AREC. The co-broker also agrees that civil action can be brought against him or her as a result of any claims that may be filed in Alabama. If a complaint is filed against the out-of- state principal broker, the regulatory body in that licensee’s home state will be notified. The Standard Interstate Co-Brokerage Agreement can be found on the AREC website at AREC - Forms . Accessing it requires an online services login. www.arec.alabama.gov/pages/forms.aspx LICENSE STATUS Definition of a licensee Transfer of license to different qualifying Broker and fee Evidence of transfer Definition of an inactive license Recovery fund fee exemption Reactivation of an inactive license Return of license The status of an Alabama real estate license can be  active: allows the licensee to legally practice the business of real estate  inactive: still valid but restricts the licensee from legally practicing the business of real estate  expired: not renewed prior to September 30 of the final year of the license period; an expired license is on inactive status  lapsed: not renewed within the 12 months following the expiration date; a lapsed license may not be renewed or reactivated. Definition of a licensee Alabama law defines a licensee as any real estate broker, salesperson, or company that is licensed as such under the requirements of Alabama license law. Salespersons are licensed under and must work under the supervision of a qualifying broker. Brokers can be associate brokers or qualifying brokers. Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 453

A company is any sole proprietorship, corporation, partnership, branch office, or lawfully constituted business organization which is licensed as a company under Alabama license law. A broker or salesperson's license is registered to a specific real estate office and is issued to and held by a person who meets all of the requirements of Alabama license law. Transfer of license Although a salesperson or broker must be registered under a specific real estate office and qualifying broker, the licensee may want to work for another qualifying broker at some point in time. In this case, the licensee can transfer his or her license to the other qualifying broker. To transfer, the licensee must give notice of his or her intent to transfer in writing to the Commission and send a copy of the notice to his or her current qualifying broker. The licensee must also pay a $25 transfer fee. The new qualifying broker must file a request for the transfer with the Commission along with a statement assuming liability for the transferred licensee. A company or sole proprietorship wishing to change qualifying brokers must also pay a license transfer fee for the license or licenses that contain the current and the new qualifying broker's names. Companies with branch offices wishing to change the qualifying broker for the main office will pay a license transfer fee for each branch office license and each branch office qualifying broker's license. When transferring to a new qualifying broker, the licensee must mail his or her license by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the Commission office along with the required transfer forms, license certificates, and fee(s). If the required forms and fees are submitted within 10 days after the Commission receives the notice of transfer, the Commission will issue a new license certificate to the licensee for the remainder of the current license term. The new license certificate will be registered under the new qualifying broker. If the necessary forms and fees are not submitted within the 10 days, the transfer is null and void. The Commission will then return any submitted forms and fees along with a notice to the licensee that the transfer was not complete. If the transfer is not completed, the current qualifying broker remains responsible for the licensee's actions. Evidence of transfer When the licensee mails the transfer documents and fee to the Commission, he or she should keep the mail receipt as evidence of the license transfer. The date of the mailing shown on the receipt will be the effective date of the transfer as long as all of the necessary forms and fees were submitted by the required deadline. Definition of an inactive license An inactive license is one that restricts the licensee from performing any real estate acts that require a license. Only an active license allows the licensee to legally engage in real estate activities. 454 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

A license is inactive when  being held by the AREC as a result of a legal action, an order of the Commission, or at the request of the licensee  the Commission issues it to inactive status at the licensee’s request  it is still renewable but the licensee failed to renew it by the deadline  an individual with a temporary license does not complete the post- license education requirements and apply for an original (permanent) license within the first 6 months of temporary licensure; in this case, the temporary license becomes inactive for the second 6 months of temporary licensure. Inactive licenses are held at the AREC office until they are activated. To engage legally in real estate activities, the licensee must reactivate his or her license by following the procedure outlined in Alabama license law and the AREC rules. The procedure is explained below. Recovery Fund fee exemption A licensee is not required to pay a Real Estate Recovery Fund fee when his or her license is issued on inactive status. However, the licensee must pay the fee before he or she can activate the license. If the Commission charged a supplemental Recovery Fund fee while the license was in inactive status, the licensee must also pay that supplemental fee before activating the license. Reactivation of an inactive license Any licensee who wishes to reactivate his or her inactive license must apply to the AREC for an activated license and pay the required fee(s). The fee(s) is charged for each license being changed from inactive to active, but no fee is charged for a license being changed from active to inactive. In addition to applying for reactivation and paying the fee(s), the licensee must also have completed the required 15 hours of continuing education for the current license period prior to requesting reactivation. The licensee will be required to complete an additional 15 hours of continuing education to qualify for license renewal for the next license period. For example, let's say that Jim's broker license has been on inactive status for 4 years. In April of the fourth year, Jim applies for reactivation. Jim must complete 15 hours of continuing education for the current 2-year license period that willl end in the upcoming August. Then, by August 31 of that same year, Jim will also need to complete an additional 15 hours of continuing education to renew his license for the next 2-year license period. Return of license If a corporation, partnership, or individually owned company wishes to stop a broker or salesperson from doing business in its name, the entity can notify the Commission and the broker or salesperson in writing and return the broker or salesperson's license to the Commission. 27 Alabama Brokerage 27 Regulation Broker and Company Licenses Trust Funds Estimated Closing Statements Advertising Recordkeeping BROKER AND COMPANY LICENSES Issuance of broker licenses Company and branch office licenses Responsibilities of qualifying broker Broker supervision Termination of qualifying broker status Qualifying broker for more than one company Temporary qualifying broker Place of business Teams All Alabama real estate salesperson and broker licenses are registered to a specific real estate office. Any individual wishing to be licensed as a broker in Alabama must apply for a broker's license using an AREC-designated form which specifies the real estate office under which the individual is registered. The individual must also meet the education, experience, and personal requirements for becoming an Alabama broker. Issuance of broker licenses General requirements. Individuals who want to obtain an Alabama real estate broker license must meet the same personal requirements as those necessary to obtain a salesperson license. An applicant must be  a U.S. citizen or permanent resident alien, or be legally present in the U.S.  at least 19 years old  a high school graduate or the equivalent  a resident of any U.S. state  free of any conviction for a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude  free of any rejection of a real estate license application or revocation of a real estate license in any state within the previous 2 years 460 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

The broker applicant must provide the same documentation an applicant for a salesperson license must provide (as discussed in detail in the previous chapter) as proof of meeting these requirements. Criminal background. Just as when applying for a salesperson license, if the applicant has been convicted of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude, he or she may file an "Application for Determination of Licensing Eligibility" form with the Commission. The Commission will review the conviction(s) and determine if the applicant is eligible for licensure in Alabama. Additionally, the AREC requires both state and national criminal history checks to be performed on any applicant for licensure. The applicant must submit any required information and fingerprints to the Commission, to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to the Alabama State Law Enforcement Agency or its successor, or to a fingerprint processing service approved by the Commission. Fingerprints are to be submitted on the approved fingerprint card. The AREC may then use the criminal history to determine the qualifications and fitness of the applicant to hold a real estate license. The applicant is responsible for the cost of the criminal history check which must be current to the date of license issuance. Salesperson experience. The broker applicant also must have been licensed as an active real estate salesperson in any state for at least 24 months before applying for a broker license. The 24 months of licensure must have occurred within the 36 months prior to applying for the Alabama broker license. Proof of this licensure must be submitted to the Commission along with the broker license application. Coursework and state examination. Additionally, the broker applicant must complete a 60-hour AREC-approved broker pre-license real estate course. After the applicant has met all requirements, he or she must apply to take the national and state broker licensure examination, pay the examination fee, and pass the examination with a score of at least 70%. The examination must be taken and passed within 6 months of course completion. When the applicant has met all requirements, including passing the examination, he or she will apply for the broker license. Once the broker license is issued, the broker's salesperson's license automatically terminates. The salesperson's license certificate is to be returned to the Commission for the broker's license to be issued. An applicant for a broker's license must maintain a place of business. Associate broker status. According to Alabama license law, all brokers must be registered to a real estate business and under the business's qualifying broker. Once registered, the broker becomes an associate broker with that qualifying broker. By definition, an associate broker is any broker other than a qualifying broker, made so by his or her relationship with the qualifying broker. Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 461

Company and branch office licenses The Alabama Real Estate Commission defines a company as "any sole proprietorship, corporation, partnership, branch office, or lawfully constituted business organization as the Legislature may provide from time to time." Corporations, LLCs, and sole proprietorships are the most common examples of companies under Alabama law. The other common entity defined as a company is a branch office. Alabama license law requires every qualifying broker and every place of business to have a company license. License application. The company's qualifying broker is responsible for applying for a company license or branch office license. The application must be made on an AREC-approved form. Branch office licenses use a special application form because the law requires that the branch qualifying broker and the main company qualifying broker both share responsibility for the actions at the branch office. The qualifying broker is required to be an officer, partner, or employee of the company. The company license applicant must maintain a place of business. If the applicant maintains more than one place of business in Alabama, he or she needs a company or branch office license for each location or branch office. The company must meet the following requirements for licensure:  the application must include the location of the company or branch office and the name of its qualifying broker  each company or branch office must be under the direction and supervision of a qualifying broker who is licensed at the company or branch office address  each company or branch office must have its own qualifying broker with no qualifying broker serving more than one location  the branch office qualifying broker and the company qualifying broker are to share equal responsibility for the activities of all licensees assigned to the branch office or company Every activity that requires a real estate license must be performed in the name of the licensed company under the qualifying broker. If the qualifying broker declines to support certain types of business activities, the salespersons and brokers working for that company must not engage in those activities. For example, let's say that qualifying broker Bob does not want to include property management in the services offered by his company. Bob has several associate brokers who want to manage property, so they decide to manage property on their own and not under Bob. Bob has told them he doesn't care as long as he doesn't have to deal with the activities. Bob has also told them that they cannot use the company name when offering and performing the property management services. This seems workable for all involved, right? However, it is against Alabama license law because every activity a licensee performs must be performed in the name of the licensed company and under the qualifying broker. Therefore, the 462 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

associate brokers may not manage property unless Bob agrees to include that service in his company offerings so the brokers can manage property in Bob's company name and under Bob. Each company license expires at midnight on September 30 of the final year of the license period. Qualifying broker requirements. To serve as a qualifying broker, the individual must be an Alabama-licensed broker with real estate being his or her principal business. The individual must also be in a position to supervise the real estate activities of any associate broker or salesperson registered to that office. Serving as a qualifying broker is a full time position, so the individual must be available to serve full time. Responsibilities of qualifying broker Salespersons and associate brokers must be licensed under a qualifying broker who is then responsible for real estate activities in which the salesperson or associate broker engage. The qualifying broker is also responsible for all real estate activities of the company for which he or she is the qualifying broker. The qualifying broker must also assure that all transactions performed by any licensee or company for which he or she is responsible comply with Alabama license law and AREC rules. If a licensee or company for which the qualifying broker is responsible violates any of these laws or rules, the qualifying broker will be held responsible to the injured party for any damage caused by the violation. The qualifying broker's liability will be in addition to the licensee's own liability for such violations. The qualifying broker is also responsible for displaying the current licenses for all companies, branch offices, brokers, and salespersons under his or her supervision. The licenses must be publicly displayed at the place of business. Even though the law requires the qualifying broker to supervise the associate brokers and salespersons licensed under him or her, the law is not meant to establish an employer-employee relationship. The broker and licensee may establish such a relationship, but the law does not automatically establish it for them. Broker supervision One of the primary responsibilities of a qualifying broker is proper supervision of the broker’s company and of those licensed under the broker. Proper supervision includes, but is not limited to, the following:

  • maintain an active broker’s license with the Commission
  • prevent unlicensed persons from engaging in activities requiring a license on

behalf of the qualifying broker or company

  • prevent a licensee from conducting licensed activity for a company under

which the licensee is not licensed

  • prevent a person whose license is expired, inactive, pending transfer

suspended, or revoked from engaging in licensed activities

  • ensure that licensees comply with any restrictions placed on their licenses
  • refrain from causing licensees to violate a state, federal, or local law or

regulation while conducting licensed activity Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 463

  • prevent licensees from violating state, federal, local or license law while

conducting licensed activity when the broker knows or should know of the impending violation

  • take timely action to correct or mitigate a violation of license law or

regulation on learning of the violation

  • ensure that contracts and forms used by licensees are accurate and in

compliance with statutes, rules, and office policies.

  • ensure that licensees are able to communicate effectively with the

supervising broker, branch broker, or a competent designee

  • ensure that the company and its licensees handle funds and other property

belonging to others properly

  • ensure that the company’s advertisements and those of its licensees conform

with license laws and rules

  • provide necessary orientation for licensees newly affiliated with the

company. Termination of qualifying broker status An individual may change his or her status as qualifying broker for a licensee by notifying the licensee and the Commission in writing. Remember, each licensee must be registered under a qualifying broker. So, if the qualifying broker wants to cease being a licensee's qualifying broker, he or she must send the licensee's license certificate back to the Commission. The Commission will then issue a new license certificate registered to a new qualifying broker. If the license has been lost or destroyed, the qualifying broker must verify that in writing to the Commission. An individual may terminate his or her status as a qualifying broker for a company by providing written notice to the company or to the qualifying broker of the parent company. He or she must also notify the Commission. Licensees and companies whose qualifying broker has terminated his or her status as such may not perform any acts for which a license is required until a relationship with a new qualifying broker has been established and a new active license has been issued by the Commission. Qualifying broker for more than one company Brokers may not serve as the qualifying broker for more than one company or for a company and him or herself unless the following requirements are met:  the qualifying broker must obtain the written consent of all companies for which he or she wishes to serve  the qualifying broker must file a copy of the written consent with the commission  all of the companies share the same company address The qualifying broker's licensees may be engaged by one or all of the companies for which the qualifying broker serves. Temporary qualifying broker Should a company's qualifying broker die or become disabled, the company license will become invalid. Within 30 days of the qualifying broker's death or disability, the corporation or the remaining partners may designate another 464 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

officer, member, or salesperson to apply for a license as a temporary qualifying broker. The person designated must be a broker or have been a licensed salesperson for at least 1 year prior to the application being submitted. If the application is granted, the company is allowed to operate under the temporary qualifying broker for no more than 6 months from the date the commission issues the temporary qualifying broker license. During that 6 months, the company must designate a fully licensed broker as the qualifying broker. If the company does not designate a fully licensed qualifying broker within 6 months of the commission issuing the temporary license, the company license and all licenses under the company will be placed on inactive status by the Commission after a 2-week notice. Place of business Real estate professionals must maintain a place of business which is identified by a sign that includes the name of the company as it is licensed with the AREC. If exterior signs are allowed, the sign is to be posted outside the office so that it is plainly and readily visible to the public. If exterior signs are not permitted, the sign is to be posted inside the place of business and is to comply with the building's restrictions on signage. If allowed, the sign should be posted in the entry area and on the office door. Licensees who are located within city limits or the police jurisdiction of a municipality are to operate from an office also located in the city limits or police jurisdiction. The office must be a separate space with a business telephone and a sign identifying it as a real estate office. All business records and files are to be kept at the place of business. Maintenance of such records and files is to comply with Alabama law and AREC rules. Operating from home. Licensed brokers who live in rural areas of Alabama may operate from their homes as long as the broker sets up an office to be used specifically for conducting real estate business. The space set up as an office may not be used for living purposes. The space also may only be used by the one broker and not by other licensees who are operating under the broker's license. In other words, the broker may not conduct business as a qualifying broker who supervises associate brokers operating from the same home office space. The home office space must have a separate business telephone, a separate entrance, and a sign that identifies it as a real estate office. Teams In many real estate companies, individual licensees team up with other professionals to form an official team to provide real estate services. In Alabama, a team is defined as two or more licensees who join forces to offer real estate services as a distinct group. A real estate licensee may only be a member of one team. A team does not need to be registered as a separate entity with AREC. While the qualifying broker designates the team leader, the qualifying broker cannot Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 465

delegate any duties reserved for qualifying brokers to that team leader. In addition, the team leader must provide a list of team members to the qualifying broker. TRUST FUNDS Purpose Trust funds defined Qualifying broker responsibilities Disbursement of trust funds Trust fund management Trust fund scams Escrow account reconciliation A trust fund account, also known as an escrow account, is a bank account set up to hold funds belonging to someone other than the real estate broker owning the account. The account is set up by the brokerage company's qualifying broker at a federally insured banking institution that is located in Alabama. The funds are held until such a time that a specific event, such as a real estate closing, takes place. Purpose When a property is being purchased, the buyer provides earnest money to the broker to be held until the purchase closes. These earnest funds are to be deposited into a bank account other than the broker's business or personal account. This trust fund account keeps the client's money separate from the broker's money. This ensures that any money the client needs to use for the real estate transaction is in a secure account that is accessible only by the client or the broker. As long as the money is held in a trust account in a bank insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), each client's funds are insured up to $250,000. Trust funds defined Alabama license law and AREC rules require a real estate licensee to deposit and account for all funds belonging to or being held for others at all times. These funds include earnest money, security deposits, and all other funds related to a contract for the sale or lease of property or a property management agreement. They are money or other items of value that the broker receives on behalf of an individual (usually the property buyer) to be held for the benefit of others in relation to any acts for which a real estate license is required. The funds may be U.S. currency (cash), checks, notes, other recognized forms of money, or other items of value. Cash is to be deposited immediately. Checks may be held for a specific length of time before being deposited if the purchase offer designates the length of time or the event that must occur prior to the check being deposited. If the offer does not state a specific time for the check to be deposited, it is to be deposited when the offer becomes a contract. 466 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

Each salesperson or associate broker must submit to his or her qualifying broker all funds that come into the salesperson or broker's possession to be held for other parties. Qualifying broker responsibilities Alabama laws and rules also require that the individual responsible for holding trust funds is to be the qualifying broker. The qualifying broker is responsible for depositing the funds belonging to others to be held in trust unless he or she is expressly relieved of the responsibility in writing. Thus, the qualifying broker is the trustee for the account. If a purchase contract involves more than one qualifying broker, any of the qualifying brokers involved in the sale may deposit and hold the funds related to the purchase. Funds being held in relation to a purchase contract, a lease, or a property management agreement are to be deposited and held by the qualifying broker who is providing these services to the property owner. If the services are provided by a secondary or successor broker, the first broker is to provide a complete accounting of the funds to the successor qualifying broker and is to transfer the funds to the successor broker. The qualifying broker who is currently providing the services to the owner is responsible to the public and to the Commission for the funds. At the request of the Commission, the current qualifying broker must immediately account for any trust funds he or she holds. The qualifying broker is to be a customer of the bank or financial institution where the trust account is held and is to be one of the persons with authority to deposit and withdraw funds from the account. He or she may write or make checks as necessary on all trust accounts set up on behalf of the company. Disbursement of trust funds The qualifying broker holding the trust funds must disburse the funds to the appropriate party or parties within 7 days of the consummation of the transaction for which the funds were being held. In other words, when the purchase is completed and closed, the funds must be disbursed within 7 days of that closing date. If the transaction does not close or there is disagreement regarding who should receive the funds, the qualifying broker must not disburse any of the funds unless there is a court order or until there is a written agreement signed by all parties. Alternatively, the broker may deposit the funds with the appropriate court under the rules of interpleader or any other lawful procedure that is applicable. The rules of interpleader remove the qualifying broker from the disbursement process and make the disagreeing parties litigate the disbursement between themselves. The qualifying broker becomes the stakeholder, and the disagreeing parties become the claimants. The stakeholder then would deposit the funds under dispute with the court, and the court would decide who is legally entitled to the funds. Thus, the qualifying broker is released from any liability regarding disbursement of the funds. Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 467

Trust fund management Proper accounting. Alabama license law has defined procedures which real estate professionals must follow in relation to trust fund accounts. The law has also assigned penalties for failing to perform any of these acts. The law requires the licensee to properly account for or remit money belonging to others that comes into his or her possession. Consequently, licensees must be able to correctly determine the amount of trust funds they are holding. Failure to do so is a violation of the law. The law also requires the broker to deposit and account for all funds belonging to others or being held for others in a federally insured account in a financial institution located in Alabama. Failure to do so is a violation of the law. No commingling. Further, the licensee is required to maintain trust accounts separate from his or her personal or business accounts to hold funds belonging to others. The trust account may hold funds belonging to multiple clients but not funds belonging to the broker. Failure to separate the broker's funds from the funds belonging to others is called commingling and is a violation of Alabama law. However, the AREC does allow the broker to keep some personal funds in a trust account to cover bank service charges or check fees. The qualifying broker can lose his or her license if the broker uses any money from the trust account for his own personal or business use. The broker is not only responsible for his or her own actions, but also for the actions of the salespersons and brokers which the qualifying broker supervises. Thus, the qualifying broker may be held responsible for any commingling, embezzling, and conversion of his or her client's money committed by associate brokers or salespersons. Violations and discipline. If a licensee violates any of these provisions of the law pertaining to trust funds and the violation is reported in writing to the AREC, the Commission or its staff may investigate the actions and records of the licensee. Just as with any other violation or complaint, the Commission may issue subpoenas and hear testimony of witnesses and require trust fund records and documents to be produced during the course of the investigation. If the Commission finds probable cause as a result of the investigation, the Commission will file a formal complaint and hold a hearing on the complaint. If the hearing determines the licensee is guilty of an alleged trust fund violation, the Commission will impose any or all of the following penalties for each act for which the licensee is found guilty:  require the licensee to complete continuing education courses in addition to the existing CE requirements  suspend or revoke the licensee's license  impose a fine of at least $100 but not more than $5,000  suspend or revoke the license and impose a fine  reprimand the licensee The Commission may suspend or revoke the license until the licensee has completed an approved continuing education course and/or made restitution to 468 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

any accounts holding funds that belong to others. The Commission may also stay the revocation or suspension and require the licensee to complete an approved education course and/or make restitution to any accounts holding funds belonging to others. Trust fund scams In this age of technology, it is common for funds to be transferred and deposited into bank accounts by way of electronic transfers. However, it is also unfortunately common for electronic hackers and scammers to use the same transfer methods to commit email and wire fraud and obtain funds belonging to others. The scammer typically hacks into an email account or impersonates the email of a party involved in a real estate transaction. Once the scammer has the email of the involved party, the scammer transmits false wiring information for the transfer of funds from the real estate transaction. The funds then are wired to the scammer's bank account and then immediately transferred to a bank out of the country, making it impossible to recover the funds. Typically, neither the scammer's bank or the victim's bank will reimburse the funds. Scammers are targeting licensees, parties to transactions, and even real estate settlement agents in Alabama and across the U.S. The following tips will help protect involved parties from falling victim to these scammers:  never send wire transfer information or any sensitive information by email. this includes bank information or routing numbers  include statements in emails that wiring instructions will not be sent by email  inform parties involved in the transaction of the scam and ask they inform the licensee of any requests involving funds transfers  if funds must be wired, contact the intended recipient on the phone and inform them of the intended transfer  do not open suspicious emails or click on suspicious links  be very careful with callers who request username or password verification  use passwords that are not easy to guess and then change them on a regular basis  keep firewall and antivirus software up to date While hackers and scammers are becoming more and more sophisticated on ways to obtain bank account information, often times simple steps and common sense can thwart their efforts. Escrow account reconciliation As the trust account holder, the qualifying broker is responsible for depositing and accounting for all trust funds in the account. Accounting for the funds requires periodic reconciliation of the broker's records with those of the bank holding the accounts. Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 469

All deposits into and disbursements from the trust account should be indicated both in the broker's records and on account statements from the bank. Any discrepancies must be accounted for and resolved. Trust fund recordkeeping. All records pertaining to funds belonging to others must be maintained for at least 3 years. The records must indicate to whom the money belongs, the date the money was deposited, the date the money was withdrawn or disbursed, and any other pertinent information. Reconciliation. The AREC suggests the following as means to reconcile the account records with the bank records:  tape canceled checks into the checkbook next to the check stub to maintain a complete record of the check without having to search statements for the check in question  prepare a continuous list of pending contracts with the amount of earnest money involved. mark off each transaction as it closes, as the money is refunded, or as it is forfeited by the buyer or seller  deduct any bank service charges from the account before the remainder of the commission is paid to prevent overdraft charges. the AREC allows additional designated funds to be deposited into the account to cover bad checks, services charges, etc.  keep pending contracts separate from closed contracts  maintain a separate escrow account for rental or leased property to distinguish it from sales contracts which will have no disbursements for repairs, owner's payments, etc.  keep written receipts of all funds that are received, whether they are cash, check, or other items of value. doing so will provide an internal means of control While Alabama law does not designate a time frame for account reconciliation, monthly reconciliations are a good course of action to maintain accurate records and to stay on top of discrepancies. Balancing the company's account records against the bank statement should be performed as soon as the statement is received. If the funds being held are security deposits or rent payments, the licensee should maintain a security deposit escrow account and a rent escrow account to hold the funds belonging to the tenants or to the property owner. The licensee should maintain a continuous ledger that includes all deposits, the tenants' names, the property address, the owner's name, the deposit amount, and the date of the deposit. Account ledgers for rent payments should also include a record of payments to the property owner as proceeds, to the real estate management company for their management fees, and invoices for any maintenance. These accounts also should be reconciled monthly with the balances shown in the ledgers matching with the balances shown on the monthly bank statement for each account. 470 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

ESTIMATED CLOSING STATEMENT Purpose for the estimate Estimated closing expenditures Disclosure to consumer A real estate closing is the transfer of the property title from the seller to the buyer in accordance with the sales contract. However, there are numerous costs associated with the closing that can become quite complex. The costs involved are determined by the sales contract, local tradition and custom, type of financing, and local, state, and federal laws. The closing statement. A closing statement is an accounting document used in the real estate transaction closing that details the final costs related to a transfer of ownership of property. It is also known as a settlement statement. While the closing statement presents the final settlement costs, buyers and sellers need to know the approximate transaction costs at the time an offer to purchase the property is made. Therefore, the law requires that an estimated closing statement be produced for both the buyer and the seller at the time an offer or counteroffer is made. The estimate approximates settlement costs so that each party will be duly informed and prepared. All parties to the transaction should compare the estimated closing statement to the final closing statement to find and correct potential errors. Providing an estimated closing statement to the buyer and seller also helps protect against mortgage fraud by eliminating the potential for unexpected and/or unexplained costs charged by the bank or mortgage company at the actual closing. Purpose for the estimate Any licensee who represents a residential buyer and obtains a written purchase offer must prepare and provide an estimated closing statement to the buyer. The statement must contain the most accurate and complete estimates of all costs that are the buyer's responsibility at the time the transaction closes. The statement must itemize not only which costs the buyer will pay but also the estimated amount of each cost. The licensee must provide the statement to the buyer at the time the buyer signs the offer to purchase. Any licensee who represents a residential seller and presents a written purchase offer to such seller must also prepare and provide an estimated closing statement to the seller. The statement provided to the seller must show which costs are the seller's responsibilities and approximately how much each of those costs will be. This statement is to be provided to the seller at the time the offer is presented. By signing the estimated and the actual closing statements, both the buyer and the seller are acknowledging that they received the statements. TILA, RESPA and TRID. Alabama license law and administrative rules protect the consumer by mandating that licensee provide an estimated closing Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 471

statement. At the same time, the Truth in Lending Act (TILA) and the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) also serve to protect the consumer. TILA- RESPA Integrated Disclosure (TRID) Rules have specific requirements for disclosure notices from the lender of a mortgage loan to the borrower. Under TRID, the Good Faith Estimate formerly provided by lenders has been replaced by the Loan Estimate, which must be provided to the borrower of a mortgage loan within 3 business days of the borrower's application for the loan. Additionally, a TRID-mandated Closing Disclosure must be provided to the borrower 3 days prior to closing on the mortgage loan. Keep in mind the difference in these mandated disclosures:  the estimated closing statement, mandated by Alabama law, is provided by the real estate licensee to inform the buyer and the seller of all costs associated to the real estate transaction closing; it is provided at the time a purchase offer or counter offer is submitted  the loan estimate and closing disclosure, mandated by federal law, are provided by the lender to inform the borrower of the costs associated with the mortgage loan; the loan estimate is provided at the time the loan application is received, and the closing disclosure is three days prior to closing, as stated Both federal and state laws work to assure the consumer is informed, prepared, and protected in real estate transactions and financing. Estimated closing expenditures The estimated closing statement includes debits and credits for both the seller and the buyer that are due at closing and the approximate amount of each. Typically, what is a debit to the seller is a credit to the buyer and vice versa. Debits for the seller would include the following:  real estate commissions to be paid  escrow fees  excise taxes, if applicable  repairs to be done based on the home inspection  prorated property taxes and assessments  title clearing  second mortgages, home equity loans, and tax liens  any other items to be paid by the seller  credits for the seller would include the following:  purchase price of the property  prorated prepaid property insurance  prorated prepaid utilities  prorated prepaid property taxes  any other agreed upon shared costs between the buyer and seller 472 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

Debits for the buyer would include the following:  purchase price of the property  escrow fees  title insurance  mortgage loan origination fee  home inspections  property surveys  prorated prepaid property insurance  prorated prepaid utilities  prorated prepaid property taxes  any other items to be paid by the buyer Credits for the buyer would include the following:  earnest money deposit  cash down payment  adjustments for the buyer's overpayment of estimated attorney fees and closing costs  repairs needed based on the home inspection but not prepaid by the seller  any other agreed upon shared costs between the buyer and seller Disclosure to consumer The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) requires that the buyer of real estate be informed about closing costs and prevents abusive practices that inflate the costs of closing for the buyer. The Act requires that the lender disclose the costs of closing to the borrower and prohibits the lender from demanding excessive deposits for escrow accounts. Providing an estimated closing statement is the means for disclosing purchasing or sellings costs that the buyer or seller will be expected to pay. Because the notification must take place at the time an offer to purchase is obtained from the buyer or presented to the seller, it assures there will be no surprises for either party at closing. Failing to disclose these estimated costs to the buyer or the seller is a violation of Alabama license law and RESPA and puts the licensee at risk of investigation by the AREC. If found guilty at a formal hearing, the licensee may have his or her license suspended or revoked, may have a $100 to $5,000 fine imposed, may be reprimanded for each instance of a guilty verdict. The licensee may also be required to complete an approved continuing education course and/or make restitution. Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 473

ADVERTISING Advertising with an interest Signage Team Advertising When advertising real estate, licensees must be honest. They are prohibited from making false promises that could potentially influence, persuade, or induce a consumer to enter into a contract. They are also prohibited from flagrant misrepresentation in any form of advertising. Publishing any advertisement that deceives the public or is likely to deceive the public is against the law. All advertisements must identify the advertiser as a licensed broker or salesperson. Advertising with an interest Alabama license law exempts property owners from licensing requirements when the owners are managing their own property or engaging in a real estate transaction involving their own property. In other words, a property owner can manage, lease, or sell his or her own property without needing to be licensed as a real estate salesperson or broker. This also means the property owner can advertise his or her own property for lease or sale without needing to be licensed. Alabama license law also allows any property owner who becomes a licensed broker or salesperson to advertise his or her own property. However, while the non-licensed owner is exempt from the license laws, the licensed owner must abide by all provisions of the law and AREC rules in any real estate transaction. This includes transactions in which the licensee is the property owner or the spouse, child, or parent of the property owner. Thus, the licensee must also comply with all applicable laws when advertising his or her own property for lease or sale. Further, if the licensee is advertising his or her own property or property belonging to a member of the licensee's immediate family, the licensee must provide prior written disclosure of his or her interest in the property to all parties to the transaction. The licensee must also disclose that he or she is a licensed real estate salesperson or broker. The law states the disclosure must be "timely" without giving a definitive time frame. If the licensee is seeking to purchase an interest in a property being sold by his or her brokerage company, the licensee must disclose his or her intention to the property seller or the seller's agent. The licensee must inform the seller that he or she is a licensed real estate salesperson or broker and that he or she is the intended buyer of the property. Signage Real estate licensees have the legal right to advertise property for sale, lease, or transfer using signs that are affixed to or located on the property itself. Alabama does not allow a municipal corporation or local government to impose a fee or tax on the signs, whether the signs are located on or near the property. However, local, county and city governments are allowed to set and enforce reasonable restrictions on the size, height, and placement of signs on private 474 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

property or a public right-of-way. Such restrictions are covered in detail in Article 1 of Chapter 54 of the Alabama Code of Ordinances. The restrictions include the manner of erection and posting of signs, interference or obstructions caused by the signs, removal and disposal of the signs, etc. Team Advertising Real estate teams have specific advertising rules that apply only to them. While the law has granted AREC the ability to adopt rules regarding the words that may and may not be used in team names and how teams may market and advertise their services, the law does proscribe a few of its own requirements. In team advertisements, the name of at least one team member and the name of the real estate company where the team members are licensed must both be included in the ad. Either “team” or “group” must be included in the team name. In addition, the qualifying broker must give written authorization to allow the team to include its name in any advertisements. RECORDKEEPING Both estimated closing statements and the actual closing statements must be retained in the broker's files. The buyer's agent should retain the estimated and actual closing statements signed by the buyer in his or her qualifying broker's files, while the seller's agent retains the statements signed by the seller. Neither licensee is required to retain statements signed by both the buyer and the seller. Nor is it necessary for cooperating brokers to maintain both the buyer's statement and the seller's statement. Although the law does not specify a time frame for retention of closing statements, as with any documents or records related to a real estate transaction, the statements should be retained for at least 3 years.
